Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports experimental research investigating molecular collisions at temperatures close to absolute zero. This "ultracold chemistry" is important for understanding the fundamental physics underlying chemical reactions as well as the chemistry of the cold interstellar medium. The research will enable the delicate tools of ultracold atomic physics to be applied to traditional chemical reactions. In this work, molecules and atoms will be cooled by a cryogenic helium gas and their collisions and chemical reactions will be studied by laser spectroscopy.

The broader impacts of this program include the training of graduate and undergraduate students in cold molecule research and many areas of modern technology, such as lasers, optics, high vacuum, and cryogenics. Potential applications include the development of new methods to control chemical reactions and chemical synthesis, a long- standing goal of physical chemistry.

Institution.Name: Board of Regents, NSHE, obo University of Nevada, Reno

Performance_Institution.Name: Board of Regents, NSHE, obo University of Nevada, Reno

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project achieved its primary goal of measuring chemical reactions at cryogenic temperatures.

First, the project successfully measured the chemical reaction of atomic lithium with molecular calcium monohydride at 1 Kelvin (one degree above absolute zero). The precise control of molecules which is possible only at cold temepratures makes these measurements a very sensitive test of the theory of chemical reactions. This will improve our understanding of the physics underlying chemical reactions, and enable a better understanding of the chemical reactions which proceed in cold interstellar space.

The project also successfully used chemical reactions at cryogenic temperatures to produce and study molecules which cannot be produced under normal conditions. The project reacted lithium atoms with helium atoms to form the lithium-helium molecule (LiHe). While helium is the most chemically inert of all substances, the project achieved experimental conditions sufficient to enable the production and observation of LiHe.

This allows the investigation of chemistry in an unexplored regime: the molecular bond of LiHe is millions of times weaker than an "ordinary" molecule, and the properties of the lithium-helium bond are dominated by quantum-mechanical uncertainty. Far from typical covalent or ionic bonds, the "van der Waals" bond of the LiHe molecule depends very sensitively on the long-range interaction of lithium and helium, and serves as a precision probe of these long-range forces. The project measured LiHe spectroscopically and determined its equilibrium thermodynamic properties.

The project supported and enabled the training of four graduate students and two undergraduate students. The experimental results were presented by graduate students at national and international conferences, and published in peer-reviewed journals.


Last Modified: 07/09/2014
Modified by: Jonathan D Weinstein

First, the project successfully measured the chemical reaction of atomic lithium with molecular calcium monohydride at 1 Kelvin (one degree above absolute zero). The precise control of molecules which is possible only at cold temepratures makes these measurements a very sensitive test of the theory of chemical reactions. The project also successfully used chemical reactions at cryogenic temperatures to produce and study molecules which cannot be produced under normal conditions. The project reacted lithium atoms with helium atoms to form the lithium-helium molecule (LiHe). While helium is the most chemically inert of all substances, the project achieved experimental conditions sufficient to enable the production and observation of LiHe. This allows the investigation of chemistry in an unexplored regime: the molecular bond of LiHe is millions of times weaker than an "ordinary" molecule, and the properties of the lithium-helium bond are dominated by quantum-mechanical uncertainty. Far from typical covalent or ionic bonds, the "van der Waals" bond of the LiHe molecule depends very sensitively on the long-range interaction of lithium and helium, and serves as a precision probe of these long-range forces.
